question_sentence: Which Kurdish insurgent group, active in Turkey for 40 years, has announced it is disbanding?
evidence: The Kurdistan Workers' Party, known as the PKK, said it would lay down its arms after a four-decade insurgency against the Turkish state, which has claimed the lives of around 40,000 people. In a statement the group said it had "completed its historical mission" and would continue its struggle on behalf of Turkey's Kurdish minority via "democratic politics".

question_sentence: The Trump administration fast-tracked refugee status for white farmers fleeing which country?
evidence: The Trump administration welcomed the first 59 white South Africans to enter the US as refugees, sparking outrage and causing the Episcopal Church to end its refugee partnership with the government. Donald Trump claimed a "genocide" was happening against white farmers in South Africa, but this "has been strongly disputed by South Africa's government, experts and even the Afrikaner group AfriForum".

question_sentence: The Cannes Film Festival has banned what from its red carpet?
evidence: An updated dress code for this year's Cannes festival specifies that "for decency reasons, nudity is prohibited". The move follows several recent high-profile incidents of celebrities baring all or nearly-all on the red carpet – notably, Bianca Censori's eye-popping see-through outfit at the Grammy Awards in February.

question_sentence: Poland will elect a new president on Sunday. Which candidate is leading the polls?
evidence: Trzaskowski, a centre-leftist and the current mayor of Warsaw, is leading the polls in round one of the presidential vote, with a second round scheduled for June. Poles are voting for a successor to Andrzej Duda, who has served two terms as president and is thus ineligible to stand again.

question_sentence: The US and China agreed to temporarily reduce their reciprocal eye-watering tariffs by how much?
evidence: After a weekend of talks in Geneva, the US and China agreed a 90-day "pause" during which US tariffs on Chinese goods will drop from 145% to 30% and Chinese tariffs on US goods from 125% to 10%. The move represents a marked shift from Donald Trump's previously hawkish rhetoric on China tariffs, leading some commentators to suggest it amounted to a U-turn.

question_sentence: Which state became the second in the US to ban fluoride from its public water supply?
evidence: Florida governor Ron DeSantis signed a bill banning fluoride and other additives from being added to public drinking water, calling it a measure to "protect against forced medication". Still, public health experts warn it could worsen tooth decay in children. The new bill is set to take effect in July, and will make Florida the second state after Utah to ban fluoride.

question_sentence: Which original film is the first in eight years to make more than $200 million at the North American box office?
evidence: The vampire horror movie directed by Ryan Coogler grossed $200 million in the US and Canada. Critical acclaim has helped the film become the highest-earning original film domestically since Pixar's "Coco," which made $210 million in 2017.

question_sentence: A photo appearing to show which world leader with a bag of cocaine has been debunked?
evidence: A crumpled white object on the table in front of the French president as he travelled to Kyiv with other world leaders on Saturday became the subject of social media speculation that it was a bag of cocaine. "This is a tissue. For blowing your nose," the Elysée Palace said on its X account, posting a close-up of the item and accusing "France's enemies" of spreading "disinformation".

question_sentence: This week saw the release of a new game in which popular first-person shooter franchise?
evidence: "Doom: The Dark Ages", a sequel to 2016's "Doom" and 2020's "Doom: Eternal", has had a positive reaction from game critics. The Guardian's Rick Lane said it offered gamers a "fascinating reformulation" of the "Doom" franchise's core ideas – as well being a lot of "fun" to play.

question_sentence: More than 1,000 Starbucks baristas went on strike over which new policy change?
evidence: Starbucks baristas across the US went on strike after the company introduced its new dress code, which will require them to wear solid black shirts and khaki, black or blue denim bottoms under their green aprons. The company says the change helps customers recognise staff, but workers argue that Starbucks is "focused on all the wrong things".

question_sentence: The Qatari royal family has offered President Donald Trump which of the following expensive gifts?
evidence: Trump said the Defense Department plans to accept the Boeing 747-8 jet and retrofit it to be used as Air Force One, which raises substantial ethical and legal questions.

question_sentence: Which Marvel star got engaged in Paris this week?
evidence: Simu Liu and his girlfriend Allison Hsu announced their engagement in a joint Instagram post.

question_sentence: Apple may owe you money for which of the following reasons?
evidence: The possible payout is part of a $95 million settlement stemming from a lawsuit about accidental Siri activations.

question_sentence: Todd Blanche, President Trump’s personal attorney, was appointed acting librarian of Congress. Whom did he replace?
evidence: Carla Hayden was the first woman and first Black person to serve as librarian of Congress. Blanche has no experience or education in library sciences.

question_sentence: Major League Baseball has decided to officially remove more than a dozen players, including Pete Rose and “Shoeless” Joe Jackson, from its permanently ineligible list for which of the following reasons?
choices: Thousands of fans signed a petition
evidence: Rose and Jackson, two of the sport’s most famous players, were kicked out of baseball for gambling on the game. In announcing the historic decision, MLB commissioner Rob Manfred wrote, “Obviously, a person no longer with us cannot represent a threat to the integrity of the game.”

question_sentence: Why was Kentucky Derby-winning jockey Junior Alvarado fined $62,000 and suspended for two racing days?
evidence: Racing regulations allow riders to whip their horses a maximum of six times per race. Alvarado hit Sovereignty eight times during the Run for the Roses.

question_sentence: Which member of President Trump’s Cabinet said, “I don’t think people should be taking advice — medical advice — from me”?
evidence: Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. made the statement when questioned about his views on vaccines during a hearing on Capitol Hill.

question_sentence: Which burger chain has agreed to remove artificial dyes from its menu items?
evidence: In-N-Out is eliminating artificial dyes from its strawberry milkshakes and pink lemonade.

question_sentence: President Trump announced plans to drop sanctions against which country this week?
evidence: Trump said lifting the sanctions on Syria will “give them a chance at greatness.”

question_sentence: Which of the following nearly knocked New Zealand cyclist Dion Smith off his bike during the Giro d’Italia?
evidence: Smith had just spotted a small herd of goats by the side of the road when one of them darted into his path.
